t: In punishment for the decree to slay the innocents, thou didst grant unto thine own, beyond all hope, abundant water,
Showing by the thirst they then endured how thou hadst punished their adversaries.
Through their trials, which were yet but a merciful correction, they understood how a judgment of wrath tormented the ungodly;
For them thou didst test as a father who admonishes, but those thou didst punish as a stern king who condemns,
And from afar as from near, they languished alike.
For a double sorrow seized them, and a groaning, at the memory of what was past;
When they learned, indeed, that even that which chastised them was a benefit to others, they acknowledged the Lord,
For him whom aforetime they had rejected in exposure, they admired at the end of events, having suffered a thirst far different from that of the righteous.
For their foolish and guilty thoughts, which led them astray in worshipping mindless reptiles and wretched beasts, thou didst send upon them in punishment a multitude of mindless animals,
That they might know that one is punished by the very things wherein he sins.
Thy all-powerful hand, surely, was not hindered - it which created the world from formless matter - from sending against them a multitude of intrepid bears or lions,
Or fierce, unknown beasts, newly created, full of fury, exhaling a fiery breath, emitting a foul smoke, or flashing terrible sparks from their eyes,
Beasts able not only to annihilate them by their wickedness, but also to cause them to perish by their terrifying aspect.
Without these even, they could have fallen by a single breath, pursued by Justice, swept away by the breath of thy power. But thou hast ordered all things in measure, number, and weight.
For thy great power is ever at thy service, and who can resist the force of thy arm?
The whole world is before thee as that nothing which tips the scales, as the drop of morning dew that falls upon the earth.
But thou hast mercy on all, because thou canst do all things, and thou overlookest the sins of men, that they may repent.
For thou lovest all that exists, and hast no abhorrence for anything thou hast made; for if thou hadst hated anything, thou wouldst not have formed it.
And how would anything have subsisted, if thou hadst not willed it? Or how would what thou hadst not called have been preserved?
In reality, thou dost spare all, because all is thine, Master, friend of life!
For thine incorruptible spirit is in all things!

Therefore dost thou reprove those who fall little by little; thou dost admonish them, reminding them of the things wherein they sin, so that, having rid themselves of evil, they may believe in thee, Lord.
The ancient inhabitants of thy holy land,
Thou hadst hated for their detestable practices, acts of sorcery, ungodly rites.
These merciless slayers of children, these eaters of entrails in banquets of human flesh and blood, these initiates, members of confraternities,
These parents who murdered defenseless beings, thou hadst wished to make perish by the hands of our fathers,
So that this land, which of all is most dear to thee, might receive a worthy colony of children of God.
Even those, because they were men, thou didst spare, and thou didst send hornets as forerunners of thine army, to exterminate them little by little.
Not that it was impossible for thee to deliver the ungodly into the hands of the righteous in a pitched battle, or to annihilate them in one blow by means of cruel beasts or an inexorable word;

But in exercising thy judgments little by little, thou didst leave room for repentance. Yet thou didst not ignore that their nature was perverse, their malice innate, and that their mentality would never change;
For it was a race accursed from the beginning. And it was not through fear of anyone that thou didst grant impunity to their faults.

For who will say: What hast thou done? Or who will oppose thy sentence? And who will cite thee in court for having made nations perish which thou hast created? Or who will stand against thee as the avenger of unjust men?
For there is no God besides thee who cares for all, that thou shouldst have to show him that thy judgments have not been unjust.
Nor is there any king or sovereign who can look thee in the face concerning those whom thou hast chastised.
But, being just, thou rulest the universe with justice, and thou considerest that condemning one who should not be chastised would be incompatible with thy power.
For thy strength is the principle of thy justice, and dominion over all makes thee spare all.
Thou showest thy strength if one does not believe in the fullness of thy power, and thou confoundest the audacity of those who know it;
But thou, controlling thy strength, judgest with moderation, and thou dost govern us with great leniency, for thou hast only to will, and thy power is there.
By acting thus, thou hast taught thy people that the righteous must be friends of men, and thou hast given thy sons the fair hope that after sins thou givest repentance.
For if those who were the enemies of thy children and destined for death, thou didst punish with so much care and indulgence, giving them time and place to rid themselves of their malice,
With what circumspection hast thou not judged thy sons, thou who, by oaths and alliances, hast made such fair promises to their fathers?
Thus, when thou chastisest our enemies with measure, thou teachest us to think of thy goodness when we judge, and, when we are judged, to count on thy mercy.
That is why also those who had led an insane life in injustice, thou hast tortured by their own abominations;
For they had wandered far on the paths of error, taking for gods the vilest and most despised of animals, deceived like very young children without intelligence.
So, as to children without reason, thou didst send them a derisive judgment.
But those who had not allowed themselves to be warned by a derisive rebuke were to undergo a judgment worthy of God.

Upon those beings that made them suffer and against which they raged, those beings that they held for gods and by which they were chastised, they saw clearly, and him whom formerly they refused to know, they recognized as the true God. And that is why the ultimate condemnation fell upon them.

Yes, vain by nature are all men in whom was found ignorance of God, who, starting from visible goods, have not been able to know Him-who-is, and who, considering the works, have not recognized the Artificer.
But it is fire, or wind, or swift air, or the starry vault, or impetuous water, or the luminaries of heaven, princes of the world, that they have considered as gods!
If, charmed by their beauty, they have taken them for gods, let them know how much their Master is superior, for it is the very source of beauty that created them.
And if it is their power and their activity that have struck them, let them deduce how much more powerful is He who formed them,
For the greatness and the beauty of creatures, by analogy, make one contemplate their Author.
These, however, deserve only a slight blame; perhaps indeed they only go astray in seeking God and in wanting to find him:
Versed in his works, they explore them and let themselves be taken by appearances, so much is what one sees beauty!
And yet they too are not pardonable:
If they have been able to acquire enough knowledge to postulate the unity of the world, how have they not sooner discovered the Master!

But wretched are they, with their hopes placed in dead things, those who have called gods the works of men's hands, gold, silver, treated with art, figures of animals, or useless stone, work of an antique hand.
And here is another woodcutter: he saws a tree easy to handle, he carefully scrapes off all its bark, he works it skillfully, he forms it into an object fit for the uses of life.
As for the waste from his work, he uses it to prepare his food and he is satiated.

And the waste that remains and that is good for nothing, a twisted wood pushed all in knots: he takes it and sculpts it with the application of the hours of leisure, he shapes it, with the know-how of the moments of relaxation; he gives it a human figure,
Or he makes it like some vile animal, covers it with vermilion, reddens the surface with sanguine, covers all its stains with a coating.
Then he makes it a niche that suits it, places it in a wall and secures it with iron.
Thus he watches to see that it does not fall, knowing well that it is incapable of helping itself, for it is only an image, and it needs help!
Yet, if he wants to pray for his goods, his marriage, his children, he is not ashamed to address the word to this lifeless object; for health, he invokes what is weak,
For life, he implores what is dead, for help, he begs what has the least experience, for a journey, what cannot even use its feet,
For a gain, an enterprise, the success of the work of his hands, he asks for vigor from what has not the slightest vigor in its hands!
Another who takes to the sea to cross the fierce waves invokes with loud cries a wood more fragile than the boat that carries him.
For this boat, it is the thirst for gain that conceived it, it is the wisdom of the craftsman that built it;
But it is thy Providence, O Father, that pilots it, for thou hast put a way even into the sea, and in the waves a sure path,
Showing that thou canst save from everything, so that even without experience one may embark.
Thou dost not want the works of thy Wisdom to be sterile; that is why men entrust their very lives to a tiny piece of wood, cross the waves on a raft and remain safe and sound.
And in fact, in the beginning, while the proud giants were perishing, the hope of the world took refuge on a raft and, piloted by thy hand, left to future centuries the germ of a new generation.
For blessed is the wood by which justice comes,
But cursed is the manufactured idol, it and he who made it, he, for having worked on it, and it because, corruptible, it has been called god.
For God detests equally the ungodly and his ungodliness,
Yes, the work will be chastised with the worker.
There will be a visitation even for the idols of the nations, because, in the creation of God, they have become an abomination, a scandal for the souls of men, a snare for the feet of the foolish.
The idea of making idols was the origin of fornication, their discovery corrupted life.
For they did not exist in the beginning, and they will not always exist;
It is by a human illusion that they made their entry into the world, so a prompt end has been reserved for them.

For a father afflicted with untimely mourning, when he hath made an image of his child soon taken away, now honoured him as a god, which was then a dead man, and delivered to those that were under him ceremonies and sacrifices.
Thus in process of time an ungodly custom grown strong was kept as a law, and graven images were worshipped by the commandments of kings.

Whom men could not honour in presence, because they dwelt far off, they took the counterfeit of his visage from afar, and made an express image of a king whom they were desirous to honour: that by this their diligence, they might honour him that was absent, as if he were present.
Also the singular diligence of the artificer did help to set forward the ignorant to more superstition.
For he, willing to please one in authority, forced all his skill to make the resemblance of the best fashion.
And so the multitude, allured by the grace of the work, took him now for a god, which a little before was but honoured as a man.
And this was an occasion to deceive the world: for men, serving either calamity or tyranny, did ascribe unto stones and stocks the incommunicable name.
Moreover this was not enough for them, that they erred in the knowledge of God; but whereas they lived in a great war of ignorance, those so great plagues called they peace.
For whilst they slew their children in sacrifices, or used secret ceremonies, or made revellings of strange rites;
They kept neither lives nor marriages any longer undefiled: but either one slew another traiterously, or grieved him by adultery.
So that there reigned in all men without exception blood, manslaughter, theft, and dissimulation, corruption, perfidiousness, tumults, perjury,
Disquieting of good men, forgetfulness of good turns, defiling of souls, changing of kind, disorder in marriages, adultery, and shameless uncleanness.
For the worshipping of idols not to be named is the beginning, the cause, and the end, of all evil.
For either they are mad when they be merry, or prophesy lies, or live unjustly, or else lightly forswear themselves.
For insomuch as they put their trust in idols, which have no life; though they swear falsely, yet they look not to be hurt.

Howbeit for both causes shall they be justly punished: both because they have thought wrongly of God, giving heed unto idols, and also have forsworn themselves deceitfully, in that they despised holiness.
For it is not the power of them by whom they swear: but it is the just vengeance of sinners, that shall alway pursue the offence of the ungodly.
But thou art gracious and true, longsuffering, and in mercy ordering all things.
For if we sin, we are thine, knowing thy power: but we will not sin, knowing that we are counted thine.
For to know thee is perfect righteousness: yea, to know thy power is the root of immortality.
